awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: The neurocircuitry of spider web-building
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Understanding complex behaviors occurring over long time scales is a substantial challenge in neuroscience. Orb-web weaving spiders present a unique example of animal construction that is an innate behavior (encoded in the genome) performed by an animal with a relatively small and easy to study nervous system. A web is a record of a spider’s movements (as it trails silk) and follows simple geometric rules with few sensory inputs. Despite this simplicity, the neuroscience of spider web-building has received limited attention. This project uses the hackled orb-weaver, Uloborus diversus, as a model organism for creating a map of the spider’s brain that identifies the neurocircuitry that controls web-building. Orb-web building is a readily understandable behavior, and the non-venomous U. diversus (and its webs) can be easily transported for public introductions to spider behavioral neuroscience; the Fellow will pursue teaching and outreach opportunities in science museums and in the Baltimore school district using this unique feature of the study system.

The aims of this project are to reveal the circuitry governing orb web-building in U. diversus by 1) establishing a brain atlas of the major neurotransmitter/neuromodulator systems through immunohistochemistry, 2) imaging expression of a putative immediate-early gene homolog by fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) to mark active neuronal populations at different stages of web-building, and 3) investigating the expression and behavioral influence of ecdysone, a candidate signaling molecule in this system. The Fellow will gain training in spider neurobiology, and the application of modern molecular techniques such as small molecule FISH to whole-mount brain preparations in this novel model. Furthermore, this project will provide experience with computational methods, including the use of alignment and registration algorithms in creating a spider brain atlas, and familiarity with machine vision and deep learning, which is relied upon for analysis of spider behavior and web construction. Pursuit of these aims will provide opportunities for mentorship, including with undergraduates who will be annotating an anatomical data set to be incorporated into the atlas. The completed atlas will be made publicly available and serve as a foundational tool and entry-point for other researchers interested in spider neuroscience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Orb-weaving spiders perform a stunning and rare feat of animal construction, made more impressive by the fact that this innate behavior is accomplished by an animal with a relatively modest nervous system. As such, orb-weaving spiders present a tractable and promising model system to study how complex, long time scale behaviors are encoded within the nervous system. Comparatively little is known about the neuroanatomy of orb-weaving spiders, and the structures and neuronal circuits controlling web-building remain to be discovered. The main goal of this project was to advance understanding of the neural basis of orb web-building by establishing a comprehensive neuroanatomical atlas using contemporary techniques, and employing targeted methods to probe neuronal populations which may be involved in the behavior.

The fellow has created a three-dimensional atlas of the brain of the orb-weaving spider, Uloborus diversus, by imaging and computationally aligning whole-mounted immunostained brains, revealing the expression patterns for most of the major neurotransmitter, neuromodulator, and select neuropeptide-expressing populations. This atlas is the first of its kind for a spider species, and represents among the most detailed descriptions of the neuroanatomy of an orb web-building spider, to date. The dataset provides for comparative analysis on varied characteristics of the orb-weaver brain, contributes many details of innervation patterns of neuronal subtypes to known brain structures, and has also led to the discovery of new neuropil structures, not previously noted in brains of spiders under study. Distinctive circuit and neuropil elements in orb-weavers are candidate regions for the control of web-building. The novel neuropils, when considered as a unit with the arcuate body, bear a resemblance to the central complex of insects, which if substantiated, would have broader implications for understanding the evolution of higher-order processing centers within the brains of arthropods. A manuscript detailing the atlas is now in preparation for submission. Concurrently with publication of the work, the three-dimensional atlas will be hosted online in an interactive form, and will be a resource accessible to researchers, as well as members of the interested public.

The question of which brain regions and neuronal populations govern web-building has not been advanced for many decades since the pioneering work of Dr. Peter Witt. The fellow employed a spider homolog of an immediate-early gene to visualize neurons whose activity correlated with the performance of web-building, using in situ hybridization in whole-mounted brains. These preliminary findings thus reveal a potential subset of neurons engaged during web construction, and the future refinement as well as annotation of the chemical signals employed by these populations will further hone the neural basis of web-building. These results should serve as a basis for a future publication. This methodology, along with the establishment of an atlas provides a neuroanatomical foundation for spider neuroscience in U. diversus, an emerging model in which to study the overarching question of the neural basis and encoding of complex behavior.

During the course of the fellowship, the PI has developed mastery of techniques involving a novel model system, acquiring training in spider neurobiology, further developing abilities in whole-mount immunohistochemistry and in situ hybridization, confocal imaging, as well as programming, image volume registration, annotation and 3D rendering. The fellow has presented findings of this project at major conferences, both for the field of arachnology as well as neuroscience at large, contributing to the fellow’s professional development, and disseminating knowledge to other spider researchers, as well as introducing the work to the broader neuroscience community. The tenure of this fellowship has supported mentorship and outreach to the Baltimore public broadly, ranging from K-12 school students to adults, as well as the personal mentorship of an undergraduate student. These opportunities have provided hands-on experiences with spiders, neuroscience education and exposure to basic research, and have promoted interest and understanding of an often feared but fascinating animal.
